argumentText:
First we note that there are two different cases: Either the line
connecting $X$, $Y$ and $Z$ intersects two sides of the triangle or none
of them. So in the first case that it intersects two of the triangle’s
sides we get the following picture:

![image](menelaus.eps)

From this we follow ($h_1$, $h_2$ and $h_3$ being undircted):
$$\begin{aligned}
\frac{AZ}{ZB}& = &-\frac{h_1}{h_2}\\
\frac{BY}{YC} & = & \frac{h_2}{h_3}\\
\frac{CX}{XA} & = & \frac{h_3}{h_1}.\end{aligned}$$ Mulitplying all this
we get:
$$\frac{AZ}{ZB}\cdot\frac{BY}{YC}\cdot\frac{CX}{XA} = -\frac{h_1h_2h_3}{h_2h_3h_1} = -1.$$

The second case is that the line connecting $X$, $Y$ and $Z$ does not
intersect any of the triangle’s sides:

![image](menelaus2.eps)

In this case we get: $$\begin{aligned}
\frac{AZ}{ZB}&=&-\frac{h_1}{h_2}\\
\frac{BY}{YC}&=&-\frac{h_2}{h_3}\\
\frac{CX}{XA}&=&-\frac{h_3}{h_1}.\end{aligned}$$ So multiplication again
yields Menelaus’ theorem.
